title: Did you have to go into work during the blizzard?
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: Gov. Maura Healey declared a state of emergency in Massachusetts due to a major blizzard with up to 20 inches of snow forecast.
Some non-essential workers are expected to report to work despite state recommendations to stay off roads and work remotely.
Certain employers offer accommodations like hotel rooms for essential staff to maintain operations during the storm.

title: Mass. plow driver survives near-impalement when tree limb crashes through truck windshield
author: Heather Alterisio
bullets: A Kingston plow driver's truck was nearly impaled by a falling tree branch during a severe winter storm.
The branch pierced the windshield, narrowly missing the driver and causing no injuries, Kingston Police confirmed.
Blizzard conditions have caused widespread power outages and service interruptions in Massachusetts, with up to 24 inches of snow expected.

title: Citing ‘hate’ and child exploitation, AG Campbell logs off X
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Attorney General Andrea Campbell leaves X, citing platform's promotion of hate and child exploitation.
Campbell criticized X's lack of accountability and highlighted issues with AI chatbot Grok's misuse.
Massachusetts AG plans to use social media alternatives like Bluesky and Threads for future communications.

title: Pregnant woman hospitalized after ICE detention in Burlington
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Djeniffer Benvinda Ribeiro Semedo, a 22-year-old pregnant woman, was detained by ICE in Burlington, MA, causing a health crisis.
Ribeiro Semedo was hospitalized for complications during detention, leading to her eventual release after legal intervention.
ICE's detention of Ribeiro Semedo violated a 2021 policy against detaining pregnant individuals, according to court documents.

title: Amtrak service between Boston and New York suspended due to nor’easter
author: Kristi Palma
bullets: Amtrak suspended service between New York and Boston due to a nor'easter with 60-70 mph winds affecting the region.
Gov. Maura Healey declared a state of emergency as 18-24 inches of snow is expected in New England.
Logan Airport canceled nearly 1,000 flights Monday morning due to the severe weather conditions.

title: ‘He said that?’: Joe Mazzulla’s reaction to Pat Riley’s Boston trash talk
author: Hayden Bird
bullets: Joe Mazzulla enjoyed Pat Riley's trash talk about the Celtics, saying it was 'fun' and 'awesome'.
Pat Riley made fiery comments before a Lakers statue dedication, saying it was time to 'kick some Boston ass'.
Celtics defeated the Lakers 111-89 after Riley's comments, with Mazzulla emphasizing focus on upcoming games.

title: Town-by-town snow totals: Here’s what’s fallen so far in Mass.
author: Peter Chianca
bullets: Foxborough recorded 19.3 inches of snow, the highest total in Massachusetts by Monday morning.
Boston's Logan Airport reported 5 inches of snow by 7 a.m. during the ongoing nor'easter.
Meteorologists predict 18 to 24 inches of snow, with heavy wet snow possibly causing power outages.

title: Jim Cantore experienced thundersnow live on air in Plymouth Monday morning, and freaked out
author: Peter Chianca
bullets: Jim Cantore experienced thundersnow live on The Weather Channel from Plymouth on Monday morning.
This isn't the first time Cantore has experienced thundersnow in Plymouth, with a similar event occurring in 2015.
A video comparing his reactions from both events was released by The Weather Channel on Monday.

title: Nearly 1,000 flights cancelled at Logan Airport due to nor’easter
author: Kristi Palma
bullets: Nearly 1,000 flights cancelled at Logan Airport due to a nor'easter affecting Massachusetts.
Gov. Maura Healey declared a state of emergency with expected 18-24 inches of snow and strong winds.
JetBlue is waiving change fees for flights affected by the severe weather from February 22 to 26.

title: Map: Here’s where power outages are being reported in Mass., R.I., N.H.
author: Heather Alterisio
bullets: Over 113,000 Massachusetts residents face power outages due to a nor’easter expected to bring 18-24 inches of snow.
Rhode Island has 14,000 residents without power, and New Hampshire reports nearly 200 outages from the storm.
The Cape and Islands experience severe outages and wind speeds over 70 mph from the snow and wind blitz.
